headings: News
Sudan files case against UAE at top UN court over ‘complicity in genocide’
Khartoum accuses the UAE of backing the Rapid Support Forces, which is fighting the Sudanese army in a year-long civil war.
By
Abdel Bari Atwan
Published On 6 Mar 2025
updated 6 Mar 2025
Timeline of the Sudan conflict
Sudan’s army and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have been fighting for almost a year [File: Reuters]

The Sudanese government has filed a case against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing it of supporting the rival Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in the country’s year-long civil war.

In its application to the ICJ, also known as the World Court, Sudan said it was seeking to “obtain redress for the UAE’s violations of Sudan’s sovereignty, its interference in Sudan’s internal affairs, and its use of force against the Sudanese people”.
The Sudanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement on Wednesday that it had presented evidence that the UAE provided weapons and financial and political support to the RSF.
It added that the UAE’s actions had fuelled the conflict and caused widespread destruction and human rights abuses.
The UAE has not yet officially responded to the accusations. However, it has previously denied providing military support to any of the warring parties in Sudan.
The ICJ has the authority to issue binding rulings on disputes between states. However, its decisions are not always enforced.
The conflict in Sudan erupted in April 2024, after months of escalating tensions between the army and the RSF. The fighting has killed thousands of people and displaced millions more.
The UAE has been a major investor in Sudan in recent years. It has also been a key ally of the Sudanese military.
Some analysts say that the UAE’s support for the RSF is aimed at undermining the Sudanese government and gaining influence in the country.
Others say that the UAE is simply trying to protect its interests in Sudan and prevent the country from descending into further chaos.
The Sudanese government has been under increasing pressure to end the conflict. In recent weeks, it has launched a new military offensive against the RSF.
It has also called on the international community to put pressure on the UAE to stop supporting the RSF.
The ICJ is expected to hold hearings on the case in the coming months. Its ruling could have a significant impact on the conflict in Sudan.

3.title: Sudan Takes the UAE to Court for Backing a Brutal Militia

3.og_description: Khartoum’s lawsuit against Abu Dhabi at the International Court of Justice could open a new front in the country’s civil war.
headings: Sudan Takes the UAE to Court for Backing a Brutal Militia
Khartoum’s lawsuit against Abu Dhabi at the International Court of Justice could open a new front in the country’s civil war.
By Cameron Drouin
March 17, 2025
A Sudanese soldier stands guard in Khartoum on Oct. 1.
Sudan has accused the United Arab Emirates of backing the Rapid Support Forces.  AFP via Getty Images

The Sudanese government has filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) accusing the United Arab Emirates of funding the country’s main paramilitary group, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which is accused of carrying out widespread atrocities. The move could open a new front in the country’s nearly yearlong civil war.

In its application to the ICJ, filed on Wednesday, the Sudanese government accuses the UAE of violating international law by supporting the RSF, which is fighting to overthrow the government. The government alleges that the UAE has provided the RSF with financial and military support, including weapons, training, and logistical assistance.

“The UAE has directly engaged in military actions against Sudan,” the application reads. “The UAE has provided financial support to the RSF, knowing that this support would be used to finance military operations against Sudan.”

The UAE has denied the allegations, calling them “baseless and without merit.” In a statement, the UAE’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that it “remains committed to supporting a peaceful resolution to the conflict in Sudan” and that it “has never provided military support to any party in the conflict.”

The ICJ is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations and has the authority to hear disputes between states. Its rulings are binding, but it has no power to enforce them. The court has previously heard cases involving allegations of state support for armed groups, including a case brought by Bosnia and Herzegovina against Serbia and Montenegro in 1993.

The Sudanese government’s decision to take the UAE to court is a significant escalation of the conflict. It reflects the government’s growing frustration with the UAE’s alleged support for the RSF, which has been accused of carrying out widespread human rights abuses, including the massacre of civilians.
“This is a very serious step,” said Ahmed Hussein, a Sudanese lawyer and human rights activist. “It shows that the government is determined to hold the UAE accountable for its actions.”

The case could also have broader implications for the region. The UAE has been accused of supporting armed groups in other countries, including Libya and Yemen. A ruling against the UAE in the Sudan case could embolden other countries to take similar action.
“This case could set a precedent for other countries that have been affected by the UAE’s actions,” said Hussein. “It could send a message that the UAE cannot act with impunity.”
The ICJ is expected to hold hearings on the case in the coming months. It is unclear when the court will issue a ruling.

headings: Sudan Takes UAE to World Court Over Alleged Complicity in Genocide

A damaged vehicle sits on a street in Khartoum, Sudan, on May 21, 2023. Sudan has accused the United Arab Emirates of backing the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which is accused of atrocities during the ongoing civil war. (AP Photo/Marwan Ali)
By Paul Brian March 11, 2025
Sudan has filed a case against the United Arab Emirates at the International Court of Justice, accusing the Gulf nation of supporting a paramilitary group that is accused of atrocities.

In its application to the ICJ, Sudan alleges that the UAE has violated international law by providing financial and military support to the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a paramilitary group that has been fighting the Sudanese army since April 2023.

The conflict between the Sudanese army and the RSF has resulted in a dire humanitarian crisis, with widespread reports of human rights abuses, including killings, rape and torture. The International Criminal Court has opened an investigation into alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Darfur.

Sudan accuses the UAE of providing the RSF with weapons, training and financial assistance, which it says has enabled the paramilitary group to carry out its attacks. The Sudanese government has presented evidence to the ICJ, including documents and witness testimony, which it says proves the UAE’s involvement.

“The UAE has violated its obligations under international law, including the Charter of the United Nations, the Genocide Convention and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights,” Sudan’s application to the ICJ states. “The UAE has provided support to the RSF, knowing that this support would be used to commit atrocities against the Sudanese people.”

The UAE has denied the allegations, claiming that it is neutral in the conflict and that it is only providing humanitarian assistance to the Sudanese people. However, Sudan insists that the UAE’s support for the RSF is undeniable.

“The evidence is clear,” said a spokesperson for the Sudanese government. “The UAE is supporting the RSF, and the RSF is committing atrocities against the Sudanese people. The UAE must be held accountable for its actions.”

The ICJ is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations, and its rulings are binding on member states. However, the court has no power to enforce its decisions, and it is up to the UN Security Council to ensure that its rulings are implemented.

The Sudanese government is hoping that the ICJ will order the UAE to stop supporting the RSF and to pay reparations to the victims of the conflict. It is also hoping that the ICJ’s ruling will put pressure on the international community to take action to end the conflict in Sudan.

“We are confident that the ICJ will find in our favor,” said the Sudanese spokesperson. “The evidence is overwhelming, and the law is on our side. We are determined to hold the UAE accountable for its actions, and we will not rest until justice is done.”
Edited by
Richard Ostling
Richard Ostling is a veteran religion reporter and founder of Religion Unplugged.

6.title: Another test for international justice: Sudan takes the UAE to the ICJ over its complicity in genocide
6.description: As the conflict in Sudan escalates, the country's government has filed a case before the International Court of Justice accusing the United Arab Emirates of supporting the Rapid Support Forces.
6.author: Joey Ayoub
6.og_title: Another test for international justice: Sudan takes the UAE to the ICJ over its complicity in genocide

headings: Another test for international justice: Sudan takes the UAE to the ICJ over its complicity in genocide
Translation posted 19 March 2025
A soldier of the Sudanese army stands guard at a check point in Khartoum, Sudan, on October 1, 2024. Source: AFP, used with permission.
As the conflict in Sudan escalates, the country's government has filed a case before the International Court of Justice accusing the United Arab Emirates of supporting the Rapid Support Forces.
This article is based on content written by Joey Ayoub and published on Global Voices in Arabic. An edited version is published below as part of a content-sharing agreement.

On March 6, Sudan filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) accusing the United Arab Emirates (UAE) of supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF). For almost a year, the RSF have been battling the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) for control of the country. Tens of thousands of people have been killed and over 8 million have been displaced in what is already a catastrophic situation for the country and the region.

In its application [pdf] to the ICJ, Sudan stated that it seeks “to obtain redress for the UAE’s violations of Sudan’s sovereignty, its interference in Sudan’s internal affairs, and its use of force against the Sudanese people.”

The UAE has been a key backer of Sudan’s military, especially since the 2019 overthrow of Omar al-Bashir. However, since the start of the conflict, it has been accused of supporting the RSF with weapons and other resources. The UAE has denied these accusations.

The ICJ is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations. It was established in 1945 and is based in The Hague, Netherlands. The ICJ’s role is to settle, in accordance with international law, legal disputes submitted to it by States and to give advisory opinions on legal questions referred to it by authorized United Nations organs and specialized agencies.

The ICJ’s jurisdiction is based on the consent of states. This means that a state can only be brought before the ICJ if it has consented to the court’s jurisdiction. States can consent to the ICJ’s jurisdiction in a number of ways, including by signing a treaty that gives the ICJ jurisdiction over disputes arising under the treaty.

In this particular case, Sudan is arguing that the UAE has violated a number of international treaties, including the UN Charter, the Genocide Convention, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Sudan argues that these treaties give the ICJ jurisdiction over the dispute.

It is important to note that the ICJ’s decisions are binding on states. However, the ICJ has no power to enforce its decisions. If a state fails to comply with an ICJ decision, the other party to the dispute can bring the matter before the UN Security Council, which can then take measures to enforce the decision.

While it is difficult to predict the outcome of this case, it is clear that it is a major test for international justice. If the ICJ finds that the UAE has violated international law, it would send a strong message that states cannot act with impunity. It would also provide a measure of justice for the victims of the conflict in Sudan.
Written by
Joey Ayoub
Joey Ayoub is an opinion editor at Global Voices.

headings: Top Stories
International
Sudan accuses UAE of supporting rival forces in its civil war and files case at world court
By NOHA ELHENNAWY
ASSOCIATED PRESS
March 6, 2025

FILE - Smoke rises in Khartoum, Sudan, May 21, 2023. Sudan’s foreign ministry said Wednesday, March 6, 2025, that the country has filed a case at the International Court of Justice accusing the United Arab Emirates of supporting the rival Rapid Support Forces battling Sudan’s army. (AP Photo/Marwan Ali, File)

CAIRO — Sudan has filed a case at the International Court of Justice accusing the United Arab Emirates of supporting a rival paramilitary group in its civil war, the country’s Foreign Ministry said Wednesday.

The ministry said it has presented evidence that the UAE provided weapons, financial and political support to the Rapid Support Forces, which has been battling the Sudanese army since April 2023. It said the UAE’s support fueled the conflict and caused widespread destruction and human rights abuses.
There was no immediate comment from the UAE. However, Emirati officials have previously denied providing military support to any of the warring parties.
The ICJ, which is also known as the World Court, is the United Nations’ highest court for disputes between states. Its rulings are binding but difficult to enforce.

Sudan has been rocked by violence since mid-April 2023, when months of simmering tensions between the military and the RSF exploded into open fighting. The conflict has killed more than 13,000 people, according to the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project, which tracks violence around the world. However, casualty figures are likely much higher, according to U.N. officials.

The fighting has also displaced more than 8 million people, turning Sudan into the world’s largest displacement crisis. The U.N. has warned that the conflict could plunge the country into a catastrophic hunger crisis.
Noha Elhennawy, The Associated Press

headings: Live News
What is the UAE's involvement in war-torn Sudan?
Text by:  France 24
File photo of smoke billowing over Khartoum on May 16, 2023.

Sudan has accused the United Arab Emirates of backing the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a paramilitary group accused of atrocities in the country's ongoing conflict. The Sudanese government has filed a case with the International Court of Justice (ICJ) accusing the UAE of funding the RSF.
The UAE denies the charges, but what exactly is its involvement in Sudan?

Since fighting broke out in April 2024 between the Sudanese army and the RSF, the UAE has officially maintained a neutral stance, calling for a peaceful resolution to the conflict. However, several reports and investigations have suggested that the UAE has been providing support to the RSF, which is led by Mohamed Hamdan Daglo, also known as Hemedti.

The UAE has strong economic and political ties to Sudan, and has invested heavily in the country in recent years. It has also been a key ally of the Sudanese military, which is led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan.

Some analysts say that the UAE's support for the RSF is aimed at undermining the Sudanese government and gaining influence in the country. Others say that the UAE is simply trying to protect its interests in Sudan and prevent the country from descending into further chaos.

The UAE's alleged support for the RSF has drawn criticism from human rights groups and international organizations. They accuse the UAE of fueling the conflict and contributing to the suffering of the Sudanese people.
The International Criminal Court (ICC) is also investigating alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Sudan, including those allegedly committed by the RSF.
The UAE has not commented on the ICC investigation, but it has previously denied any involvement in war crimes or crimes against humanity.

As the conflict in Sudan continues, the UAE's role in the country is likely to come under increasing scrutiny. The ICJ case filed by the Sudanese government could shed further light on the UAE's involvement and potentially lead to further action by the international community.

13.title: The Genocide Convention before the World Court again
13.description: Dr Wayne Jordash KC and David Akinnibosun examine the new case brought by Sudan against the UAE before the International Court of Justice.
13.og_title: The Genocide Convention before the World Court again
13.og_description: Dr Wayne Jordash KC and David Akinnibosun examine the new case brought by Sudan against the UAE before the International Court of Justice.
headings: Insights
The Genocide Convention before the World Court again
Dr Wayne Jordash KC and David Akinnibosun examine the new case brought by Sudan against the UAE before the International Court of Justice.
Wayne Jordash KC
David Akinnibosun
6 March 2025

On 6 March 2025, Sudan instituted proceedings against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) before the International Court of Justice (ICJ). The application concerns alleged violations of the 1948 Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide (Genocide Convention) arising out of the ongoing conflict in Sudan.

Sudan claims that the UAE has supported the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in its fight against the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF). Sudan argues that the UAE’s support for the RSF constitutes a violation of the Genocide Convention because the RSF has allegedly committed acts of genocide against certain groups in Sudan, including the Masalit community in West Darfur.

The case is significant for several reasons. First, it is one of the few cases in which a state has accused another state of violating the Genocide Convention. Second, it is the first case in which the ICJ will have to consider the question of whether support for a non-state actor can constitute a violation of the Genocide Convention. Third, the case is likely to have a significant impact on the conflict in Sudan. If the ICJ finds that the UAE has violated the Genocide Convention, it could lead to increased international pressure on the UAE to end its support for the RSF.

The ICJ has previously considered the Genocide Convention in a number of cases, including Bosnia v Serbia. In that case, the ICJ found that Serbia had violated the Genocide Convention by failing to prevent the genocide in Srebrenica. The ICJ also found that Serbia was responsible for failing to punish the perpetrators of the genocide.

The case of Sudan v UAE is likely to be a complex and lengthy one. The ICJ will have to consider a number of difficult legal and factual issues. It is likely to be several years before the ICJ reaches a decision in the case.
Dr Wayne Jordash KC is a barrister at Doughty Street Chambers. He specialises in international criminal law, human rights law and public international law.
David Akinnibosun is a barrister at Doughty Street Chambers. He specialises in international criminal law, human rights law and public international law.

headings: Ewelina U. Ochab
Senior Contributor
Human Rights
Following
Sudan Takes UAE To World Court Over Alleged Complicity In Genocide
A general view shows smoke rising in Khartoum, Sudan on May 20, 2023, amid fighting between the army and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF).
AFP via Getty Images

Sudan has filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) accusing the United Arab Emirates (UAE) of supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and of being complicit in the crime of genocide.

In its Application instituting proceedings before the ICJ, Sudan stated that it “seeks to obtain redress for the UAE’s violations of Sudan’s sovereignty, its interference in Sudan’s internal affairs, and its use of force against the Sudanese people.”

The Application also stated that  “[t]hrough its actions, the UAE has prolonged and intensified the conflict, resulting in the widespread destruction of infrastructure, countless civilian casualties, and a grave humanitarian crisis.”

The UAE has been allegedly supporting the RSF in the conflict against the Sudanese army. The conflict has been ongoing since April 2023. As reported by the UN,  both the Sudanese army and the RSF have committed war crimes. Allegations of genocide have also emerged.

As I explained earlier this week, the situation in Sudan is dire, and the international community is failing the people of Sudan. There has been a communications blackout, and the humanitarian access has been limited. The UN estimates that  25 million people need humanitarian assistance and protection. The violence has already displaced over 8 million people.

The current ICJ case is not the first case relating to the crime of genocide that is before the ICJ.  South Africa instituted proceedings against Israel concerning alleged violations of obligations under the Genocide Convention in relation to the situation in the Gaza Strip. As I  argued elsewhere, the ICJ’s Order on provisional measures in that case has been disappointing.

It is  important to note that the ICJ’s judgments are binding. However, the ICJ has no power to enforce its judgments. If a State fails to comply with a judgment of the ICJ, the other party to the case may bring the matter before the UN Security Council, which may make recommendations or decide upon measures to be taken to give effect to the judgment.

It remains to be seen what the ICJ will decide in the case of Sudan v. UAE. However, the case is significant as it highlights the importance of the Genocide Convention and the role of the ICJ in preventing and punishing the crime of genocide.
Follow me on Twitter or LinkedIn. Check out my website.
Ewelina U. Ochab

I am a human rights advocate, author and co-founder of the Coalition for Genocide Response. I have worked on a number of country-specific and thematic human rights issues at the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva, as well as on the...

15.title: Sudan Accuses U.A.E. of Fueling Genocide in Lawsuit at World Court
15.description: The complaint accuses the United Arab Emirates of supporting a paramilitary group that has been accused of atrocities in Sudan’s civil war.
15.keywords: Sudan, United Arab Emirates, War Crimes, Genocide, International Court of Justice
15.author: Declan Walsh
15.og_title: Sudan Accuses U.A.E. of Fueling Genocide in Lawsuit at World Court
15.og_description: The complaint accuses the United Arab Emirates of supporting a paramilitary group that has been accused of atrocities in Sudan’s civil war.
headings: World
Africa
Sudan Accuses U.A.E. of Fueling Genocide in Lawsuit at World Court
The complaint accuses the United Arab Emirates of supporting a paramilitary group that has been accused of atrocities in Sudan’s civil war.
By Declan Walsh
March 6, 2025
Smoke rising over Khartoum in May. Sudan’s civil war, which began last year, has caused a humanitarian disaster.

Sudan has filed a lawsuit at the International Court of Justice accusing the United Arab Emirates of fueling genocide by supporting a paramilitary group that has been accused of atrocities in Sudan’s civil war.

The complaint, filed on Wednesday at the court in The Hague, accuses the U.A.E. of violating international law by providing financial and military support to the Rapid Support Forces, or R.S.F., a militia that has been battling the Sudanese Army for control of the country since April.
The lawsuit marks a sharp escalation of the conflict, which has already caused a humanitarian disaster, displacing more than eight million people and leaving Sudan on the brink of famine.
It also opens a new front in the diplomatic war surrounding the conflict, which pits Sudan’s military rulers against the U.A.E., a wealthy Gulf state that has emerged as a major player in the region.

In its lawsuit, Sudan says the U.A.E. has provided the R.S.F. with weapons, training and financial assistance, knowing that this support would be used to commit atrocities against the Sudanese people.

“The U.A.E. has violated its obligations under international law, including the Charter of the United Nations, the Genocide Convention and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights,” the lawsuit says.

The U.A.E. has denied the allegations, calling them “baseless and without merit.” In a statement, the U.A.E.’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that it “remains committed to supporting a peaceful resolution to the conflict in Sudan” and that it “has never provided military support to any party in the conflict.”
However, the U.A.E.’s denials have been met with skepticism by many observers, who point to the country’s close ties to the R.S.F. and its leader, Gen. Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, also known as Hemedti.

The U.A.E. has been a major investor in Sudan in recent years, and has also provided the country with significant financial assistance. In 2019, the U.A.E. pledged $3 billion in aid to Sudan, and in 2020, it provided the country with a $1.5 billion loan.

Some analysts say that the U.A.E.’s support for the R.S.F. is aimed at undermining the Sudanese government and gaining influence in the country. Others say that the U.A.E. is simply trying to protect its interests in Sudan and prevent the country from descending into further chaos.
Whatever the U.A.E.’s motives, its support for the R.S.F. has had a devastating impact on Sudan, contributing to the deaths of thousands of people and the displacement of millions more.
The International Court of Justice is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations. It has the authority to hear disputes between states, and its rulings are binding.
However, the court has no power to enforce its rulings, and its decisions are often ignored by states that do not agree with them.

It is unclear whether the International Court of Justice will be able to resolve the conflict in Sudan. But the lawsuit filed by Sudan is a sign that the country is determined to hold the U.A.E. accountable for its actions.
Declan Walsh is the chief Africa correspondent. He has reported from across the continent since 2013. Before that, he covered Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq.  More about Declan Walsh

headings: Sudan files genocide case against UAE at ICJ

Sudan has filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) for allegedly supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF). The RSF is a paramilitary group that has been accused of committing atrocities in Sudan, including acts of genocide.

In its application to the ICJ, Sudan stated that the UAE has violated its obligations under the Genocide Convention by providing support to the RSF, knowing that the RSF would use that support to commit genocide. Sudan is seeking a ruling from the ICJ that the UAE is in violation of the Genocide Convention and that the UAE must cease its support for the RSF.

The ICJ is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations. It is responsible for settling disputes between states in accordance with international law. The ICJ's judgments are binding on the parties to a dispute, but the ICJ has no power to enforce its judgments.
The case of Sudan v. UAE is likely to be a lengthy and complex one. It is not clear when the ICJ will issue a ruling in the case.
Genocide Watch considers the situation in Sudan to be a serious one. We call on the international community to take action to prevent further atrocities from being committed.

headings: Sudan launches case against UAE at the International Court of Justice
The Sudanese government accused the U.A.E. of supporting a rival paramilitary group in the country’s civil war.
By  Nicolas Niarchos
March 7, 2025 at 8:41 AM EST

Sudan has filed a case at the International Court of Justice accusing the United Arab Emirates of supporting a rival paramilitary group in its civil war, the country’s Foreign Ministry said Wednesday.

The ministry said it has presented evidence that the U.A.E. provided weapons, financial and political support to the Rapid Support Forces, which has been battling the Sudanese army since April 2024. It said the U.A.E.’s support fueled the conflict and caused widespread destruction and human rights abuses.
There was no immediate comment from the U.A.E.. However, Emirati officials have previously denied providing military support to any of the warring parties.
The ICJ, which is also known as the World Court, is the United Nations’ highest court for disputes between states. Its rulings are binding but difficult to enforce.

Sudan has been rocked by violence since mid-April 2024, when months of simmering tensions between the military and the RSF exploded into open fighting. The conflict has killed more than 13,000 people, according to the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project, which tracks violence around the world. However, casualty figures are likely much higher, according to U.N. officials.

The fighting has also displaced more than 8 million people, turning Sudan into the world’s largest displacement crisis. The U.N. has warned that the conflict could plunge the country into a catastrophic hunger crisis.

19.title: Sudan sues UAE for complicit in RSF genocide in West Darfur
19.description: Sudan has filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) for allegedly supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and aiding their commission of genocide.
19.author: JURIST Staff
19.og_title: Sudan sues UAE for complicit in RSF genocide in West Darfur
19.og_description: Sudan has filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) for allegedly supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and aiding their commission of genocide.
headings: Sudan sues UAE for complicit in RSF genocide in West Darfur
Posted By: JURIST Staff
Saturday, March 8, 2025 12:38:00 AM
Smoke rises over Khartoum, Sudan, on May 21, 2023 amid fighting between the army and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF). (AFP via Getty Images)

Sudan has filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) for allegedly supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and aiding their commission of genocide, Sudan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Wednesday.

The Ministry stated that the UAE has violated Sudan’s sovereignty and interfered in its internal affairs through its support of the RSF. They also claim that the UAE has prolonged and intensified the conflict, leading to extensive destruction of infrastructure, numerous civilian casualties, and a severe humanitarian crisis.

In their application to the ICJ, Sudan seeks redress for the UAE’s actions and asserts that the UAE has breached its obligations under international law, including the UN Charter, the Genocide Convention, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The UAE has not yet responded to the lawsuit. However, they have previously denied providing military support to the RSF and have maintained that they are committed to finding a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

The conflict in Sudan began in April 2023 between the Sudanese army and the RSF. The conflict has caused a major humanitarian crisis, with millions of people displaced and in need of assistance. The UN has warned that the conflict could lead to a full-blown civil war.
JURIST Deputy News Editor Cooper French contributed to this report.

24.title: Art. IX Reservations to the Genocide Convention Are Here to Stay? A Response to Diamond
24.description: In a recent post, Ashley Diamond argues that reservations to Article IX of the Genocide Convention are incompatible with the object and purpose of the Convention. In this post, Alexander Blanchard respectfully disagrees, and argues that such reservations should be considered permissible.
24.author: Alexander Blanchard
24.og_title: Art. IX Reservations to the Genocide Convention Are Here to Stay? A Response to Diamond
24.og_description: In a recent post, Ashley Diamond argues that reservations to Article IX of the Genocide Convention are incompatible with the object and purpose of the Convention. In this post, Alexander Blanchard respectfully disagrees, and argues that such reservations should be considered permissible.
headings: Opinio Juris
Insights on International Law and Current Events
Art. IX Reservations to the Genocide Convention Are Here to Stay? A Response to Diamond
Alexander Blanchard
March 14, 2025

In a recent post, Ashley Diamond argues that reservations to Article IX of the Genocide Convention are incompatible with the object and purpose of the Convention. In this post, I respectfully disagree, and argue that such reservations should be considered permissible.
By Alexander Blanchard

Ashley Diamond’s recent post on Opinio Juris offers an insightful analysis of reservations to Article IX of the Genocide Convention. As Diamond notes, numerous states have entered reservations to Article IX, which provides that disputes between Contracting Parties relating to the interpretation, application or fulfilment of the Convention shall be submitted to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) at the request of any of the parties to the dispute. The reservations generally state that the reserving state’s consent is required before a dispute can be submitted to the ICJ.

Diamond argues that these reservations are incompatible with the object and purpose of the Genocide Convention, and therefore impermissible under Article 19(c) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties (VCLT). Diamond contends that the object and purpose of the Genocide Convention is to prevent and punish genocide, and that Article IX is essential to achieving this object and purpose because it provides a mechanism for resolving disputes about the interpretation, application, or fulfilment of the Convention. Diamond suggests that, by reserving the right to decide whether to submit a dispute to the ICJ, reserving states undermine this mechanism and weaken the Convention’s ability to prevent and punish genocide.
With all due respect, I disagree.

In my view, reservations to Article IX should be considered permissible because they do not frustrate the object and purpose of the Genocide Convention. The object and purpose of the Genocide Convention is, as Diamond notes, to prevent and punish genocide. However, Article IX is not essential to achieving this object and purpose. Article IX merely provides one mechanism for resolving disputes about the interpretation, application, or fulfilment of the Convention. It is not the only mechanism, and it is not necessarily the most effective mechanism.

Even without Article IX, states can still resolve disputes about the interpretation, application, or fulfilment of the Genocide Convention through other means, such as negotiation, mediation, conciliation, or arbitration. In fact, many states have successfully resolved disputes about the interpretation, application, or fulfilment of the Genocide Convention without ever submitting a case to the ICJ.

Moreover, it is not clear that Article IX is always the most effective mechanism for resolving disputes about the interpretation, application, or fulfilment of the Genocide Convention. The ICJ is a court of law, and its decisions are based on legal principles. However, disputes about the interpretation, application, or fulfilment of the Genocide Convention often involve complex political and moral considerations that are not easily resolved by legal principles. In such cases, other mechanisms, such as negotiation or mediation, may be more effective.

In addition, reservations to Article IX may actually encourage more states to become parties to the Genocide Convention. Some states may be hesitant to become parties to the Convention if they are required to submit all disputes to the ICJ. By allowing states to reserve the right to decide whether to submit a dispute to the ICJ, reservations to Article IX may make the Convention more attractive to these states.

To be clear, I am not arguing that reservations to Article IX are always permissible. In some cases, reservations to Article IX may be so broad or so vague that they do frustrate the object and purpose of the Genocide Convention. However, I believe that, in general, reservations to Article IX should be considered permissible because they do not frustrate the object and purpose of the Convention, and they may actually encourage more states to become parties to the Convention.
Alexander Blanchard is a recent graduate of Harvard Law School. He will be clerking on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the 2025-2026 term.

25.title: Sudan files case against UAE at UN court over Darfur genocide
25.description: The Sudanese government has officially filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the United Arab Emirates (UAE) of supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in what it describes as a genocidal campaign in Darfur.
25.og_title: Sudan files case against UAE at UN court over Darfur genocide
25.og_description: The Sudanese government has officially filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the United Arab Emirates (UAE) of supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in what it describes as a genocidal campaign in Darfur.
headings: Sudan files case against UAE at UN court over Darfur genocide

March 7, 2025 (KHARTOUM) - The Sudanese government has officially filed a case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the United Arab Emirates (UAE) of supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in what it describes as a genocidal campaign in Darfur.

In a statement released on Wednesday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced the submission of the case, asserting that the UAE’s support for the RSF constitutes a violation of Sudan’s sovereignty and interference in its internal affairs.
The Ministry further emphasized that the UAE’s actions have exacerbated the conflict, resulting in widespread destruction, numerous civilian casualties, and a severe humanitarian crisis.

“The evidence presented demonstrates the UAE’s provision of weapons, financial assistance, and political support to the RSF, thereby fueling the conflict and undermining the stability of Sudan,” the statement read.

The Sudanese government seeks redress for the UAE’s alleged violations of international law, including breaches of the UN Charter, the Genocide Convention, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The UAE has yet to respond to the accusations. However, it has consistently denied providing military support to any of the warring parties in Sudan, maintaining its commitment to a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

The ICJ, the principal judicial organ of the United Nations, is tasked with settling disputes between states in accordance with international law. Its rulings are binding, but enforcement mechanisms remain limited.

The conflict in Sudan, which erupted in April 2023, has resulted in a dire humanitarian situation, with millions displaced and facing acute shortages of food, water, and medical care. The UN has warned of the potential for further escalation and widespread atrocities if the fighting continues unabated.
(ST)
