28.title: Genocide in Sudan: How Should the ICJ Treat the Case?
28.description: Sudan has filed a genocide case against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), alleging the UAE's complicity through support for the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) accused of committing atrocities against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
28.keywords: Sudan, UAE, ICJ, RSF, Genocide, Masalit, Darfur, World Peace Foundation
28.author: Alex de Waal
28.og_title: Genocide in Sudan: How Should the ICJ Treat the Case?
28.og_description: An analysis of Sudan's genocide case against the UAE at the ICJ, focusing on the RSF's alleged atrocities against the Masalit people and the implications for international justice.
headings: Genocide in Sudan: How Should the ICJ Treat the Case?
Alex de Waal
March 20, 2025

Sudan has brought a genocide case to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in The Hague. The Court should act quickly—and not confine itself to the specific demands made by the Sudanese military leader General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan.

The United Nations-recognized Government of Sudan (GoS) has instituted proceedings against the United Arab Emirates in the International Court of Justice. The basis of the claim is that the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have committed genocide against the Masalit people of West Darfur, and that the UAE is 'complicit in the genocide on the Masalit through its direction of and provision of extensive financial, political, and military support for the rebel RSF militia.' The GoS is demanding that the Court order immediate provisional measures for the UAE to fulfil its commitments to prevent acts of genocide.

The evidence for genocidal acts by the RSF, against the Masalit and other communities elsewhere in Sudan, is strong. Human Rights Watch has spoken of 'ethnic cleansing.' The United States has issued a genocide determination. The Special Advisor to the UN Secretary-General on the Prevention of Genocide, Alice Wairimu Nderitu, has raised the alarm of similar crimes elsewhere in Darfur. The strongest case is made by the self-incriminating 'trophy' videos taken and circulated by RSF members of their own atrocities.

It’s possible that the International Criminal Court (ICC), which has a mandate for Darfur dating back twenty years, may issue arrest warrants against RSF leaders for genocide, including its leader, General Mohamed Hamdan Dagolo, known as 'Hemedti'. But unlike the ICC, which prosecutes individuals for international crimes, the ICJ deals with states only. This means that al-Burhan cannot bring the RSF as a political-military organization to court. Instead, he has turned to its sponsor.
The evidence for the UAE's support to the RSF is strong, including weapons smuggled under the cover of humanitarian flights, while UAE denials have not convinced US lawmakers.
The ICJ should hear the case promptly and issue provisional orders.
The judges at the ICJ should also go beyond the specific orders requested by the GoS, in three respects.

First, the Court should also order the UAE to do its utmost to ensure that the RSF does not commit genocide by starvation. Article 2(c) of the Genocide Convention prohibits 'Deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part.' The RSF siege of al-Fashir and the nearby camps for internally displaced persons, and attacks on essential health facilities, have been causing mass starvation there for a year. Many people in the city and the IDP camps are from the Zaghawa ethnic group, and there is good reason to believe that the RSF may be targeting them on the basis of that identity. The Court should not wait for proof that the RSF is committing genocide by starvation. It should also order the UAE to do all in its power to provide humanitarian assistance and essential services to the besieged population, both directly and through pressing the RSF to permit such assistance.

Al-Burhan’s foreign ministry has denied that famine is happening in Sudan and expelled the UN’s Integrated food security Phase Classification (IPC) for determining that it is. The Court should assess the facts, including the IPC’s objective and impartial assessment.

29.title: The jus cogens Nature of the Prohibition of Genocide in Sudan v. UAE: A New Case, the Same Old Omission
29.description: An analysis of Sudan's legal proceedings against the UAE at the International Court of Justice for alleged breaches of the Genocide Convention, focusing on the implications of the jus cogens nature of the prohibition of genocide.
29.keywords: Sudan, UAE, ICJ, Genocide Convention, jus cogens, Masalit, legal analysis, international law
29.author: Luciano Pezzano
29.og_title: The jus cogens Nature of the Prohibition of Genocide in Sudan v. UAE: A New Case, the Same Old Omission
29.og_description: An exploration of the legal consequences of Sudan's case against the UAE at the ICJ, emphasizing the peremptory norm status of the prohibition of genocide.
headings: The jus cogens Nature of the Prohibition of Genocide in Sudan v. UAE: A New Case, the Same Old Omission
Luciano Pezzano
March 18, 2025
On 5 March 2025, the Republic of Sudan instituted proceedings before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) for breaches of the Genocide Convention.

The case presents numerous legal issues, including the value of the UAE’s reservation to Article IX of the Convention, attribution of responsibility, and the fact that the victims of the alleged genocide—the Masalit people—are also victims in the case against former Sudanese President Omar Al Bashir at the International Criminal Court.
A notable omission in Sudan’s Application is the lack of emphasis on the legal consequences of genocide as a grave breach of a peremptory norm (jus cogens) of general international law.
Genocide is recognized as a peremptory norm, meaning its prohibition is absolute and non-derogable.

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) recognized the peremptory nature of the prohibition of genocide in its 2006 Judgment in the DRC v. Rwanda case and reiterated it in the 2007 Judgment on the merits in the Bosnia and Herzegovina v. Serbia case.

Other international tribunals, such as the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) and the Inter-American Court of Human Rights (IACtHR), have also recognized the peremptory status of the prohibition of genocide.
The International Law Commission (ILC) included the prohibition of genocide in its non-exhaustive list of peremptory norms in its 2022 Draft Conclusions on jus cogens.

Despite the recognition of genocide as a peremptory norm, cases before the ICJ under the Genocide Convention often omit requests for the Court to declare additional consequences for genocide, such as aggravated responsibility for the responsible State or duties for third States.

This pattern of omission undermines the hierarchical position of peremptory norms in the international legal system and the special legal consequences that should arise from serious breaches of such norms.
The article argues for the need to determine the consequences of genocide as a serious breach of jus cogens to reflect the hierarchical position of peremptory norms in the international legal system.

30.title: Could Sudan be split into two countries?
30.description: An analysis of the potential for Sudan's partition amid ongoing civil conflict between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), exploring historical precedents, current developments, and international perspectives.
30.keywords: Sudan, partition, civil war, SAF, RSF, South Sudan, international intervention, humanitarian crisis
30.author: Mohammed Amin
30.og_title: Could Sudan be split into two countries?
30.og_description: Exploring the possibility of Sudan's partition as ongoing conflicts between the SAF and RSF continue, drawing parallels with South Sudan's secession and assessing current dynamics.
headings: Could Sudan be split into two countries?
Mohammed Amin
March 15, 2025
The ongoing civil war in Sudan between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) has raised concerns about the potential partition of the country.
Historical Context: South Sudan's Independence
In 2011, South Sudan seceded from Sudan following a referendum, becoming an independent nation. This partition was the culmination of decades of conflict and negotiations.
Current Conflict and Control
As of early 2025, the SAF has made significant advances, regaining control over much of Khartoum. However, the RSF maintains strongholds in regions like Darfur and parts of Kordofan.
RSF's Parallel Government Initiative
The RSF has announced plans to establish a parallel government, termed the 'Government of Peace and Unity,' to administer areas under its control, signaling a move towards potential secession.
International Perspectives

US Special Envoy Tom Perriello has warned that Sudan risks partition or becoming a failed state if the conflict continues, emphasizing the need for a revived democratic transition to achieve lasting peace.
Humanitarian Crisis

The conflict has resulted in over 14 million displaced individuals and severe food shortages, with parts of the country facing famine. The humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate amid ongoing violence.

31.title: Sudan Takes UAE to International Court of Justice for Genocide: A Test for International Justice
31.description: An analysis of Sudan's legal action against the United Arab Emirates at the International Court of Justice, accusing the UAE of breaching the Genocide Convention by supporting the Rapid Support Forces implicated in atrocities against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
31.keywords: Sudan, UAE, International Court of Justice, Genocide Convention, Rapid Support Forces, Masalit, West Darfur, international law
31.author: Walid El Houri
31.og_title: Sudan Takes UAE to International Court of Justice for Genocide: A Test for International Justice
31.og_description: An examination of Sudan's case against the UAE at the ICJ, focusing on allegations of the UAE's support for the RSF and the implications for international justice.
headings: Sudan Takes UAE to International Court of Justice for Genocide: A Test for International Justice
Walid El Houri
March 16, 2025

On March 6, 2025, Sudan initiated legal proceedings against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the UAE of breaching the Genocide Convention by supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a paramilitary group implicated in atrocities against the Masalit people in Sudan’s West Darfur region. The UAE has denied the accusations.
Historical Accusations

The allegations against the UAE are not isolated. In October 2024, the RSF mistakenly shot down a military plane in Sudan’s Malha region, killing two Russian crew members and three Sudanese on board. The Conflict Observatory identified the aircraft as an Ilyushin Il-76, affiliated with Kyrgyzstan’s New Way Cargo, suggesting involvement in arms shipments from the UAE to the RSF. Identity documents found at the crash site included a passport and an ID of a Russian linked to a UAE-based company, Airline Transport Incorporation FZC.

Prior to this incident, the Sudanese government had been repeatedly accusing the UAE of arming the RSF and prolonging the war while profiting from “the illegal exploitation of gold.” In October 2024, Khalid Ali Aleisir, Minister of Culture and Information in Sudan, shared a video of what he claimed was evidence of UAE supplying weapons to the RSF.
Context of the War

The almost two-year-long round of violence is the fourth civil war in the country’s history. The violence, fueled by ethnic and tribal divisions, can be traced back to the rule of former president Omar al-Bashir, lasting from 1989 to 2019 before being ousted in a popular revolution. A fragile civilian-military coalition ensued but soon collapsed under a military coup led by al-Burhan in October 2021.

Following the coup, tensions increased between the military and the RSF, especially over plans to integrate the latter into the army. This culminated on April 15, 2023, when RSF units launched coordinated attacks on Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) targets, including in key locations in the capital Khartoum, marking the beginning of the war.

The RSF, originally formed from the Janjaweed militias accused of atrocities in Darfur during the early 2000s, has been implicated in severe human rights violations, including attacks on the Masalit community in West Darfur.

According to data from the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data (ACLED), by the end of November 2024, over 28,000 people have been killed, though some estimate that the real number is far higher and could be as high as 150,000.

Recent numbers from the International Organization for Migration estimate that more than 14 million Sudanese have been displaced since the beginning of the fighting in April 2023, including more than 3.5 million who have crossed the borders to seek refuge in neighboring countries. That is almost 30 percent of the total population of the country, with half the population in need of humanitarian help.

Human Rights Watch (HRW) has accused both warring parties of bombing populated areas indiscriminately, with RSF “deliberately targeting hospitals,” according to Mohamed Osman, researcher for their Africa division.
The UAE’s Role in Other Conflicts

Beyond Sudan, the UAE has faced scrutiny for its involvement in various regional conflicts. In Yemen, the UAE has been a key member of the Saudi-led coalition against Houthi rebels, a campaign criticized for causing civilian casualties and a humanitarian disaster.

32.title: UK enrages Sudanese army government by inviting UAE to London conference
32.description: The UK's decision to invite the UAE to a London conference on Sudan's humanitarian crisis, while excluding Sudan's army-aligned government, has sparked outrage in Khartoum.
32.keywords: UK, UAE, Sudan, London conference, Rapid Support Forces, RSF, humanitarian crisis, diplomatic tensions
32.author: Middle East Eye Staff
32.og_title: UK enrages Sudanese army government by inviting UAE to London conference
32.og_description: Sudan's army-aligned government expresses outrage over the UK's decision to invite the UAE to a London conference on Sudan's humanitarian crisis, citing the UAE's alleged support for the RSF.
headings: UK enrages Sudanese army government by inviting UAE to London conference
Middle East Eye Staff
March 15, 2025

The UK's decision to invite the United Arab Emirates (UAE) to a London conference addressing Sudan's humanitarian crisis, while excluding Sudan's army-aligned government, has sparked outrage in Khartoum.
Sudan's foreign ministry criticized the UK's move, stating that the presence of the UAE, alleged to support the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), reduces the conference to a 'public relations stunt.'
The conference aims to address the escalating humanitarian crisis in Sudan, which has displaced millions and led to widespread famine.
The UK's Foreign Office defended its stance, emphasizing the involvement of regional and international stakeholders to end the war and provide humanitarian aid.
Representatives from Qatar, Egypt, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia, known to favor the Sudanese army over the RSF, are also expected to participate in the conference.

33.title: Prospect of ICJ Masalit Genocide Case
33.description: An analysis of Sudan's legal proceedings against the United Arab Emirates at the International Court of Justice, alleging the UAE's complicity in genocidal acts committed against the Masalit group in Darfur by the Rapid Support Forces.
33.keywords: Sudan, UAE, ICJ, Genocide Convention, Masalit, Darfur, Rapid Support Forces, international law
33.author: Quazi Omar Foysal
33.og_title: Prospect of ICJ Masalit Genocide Case
33.og_description: An exploration of the legal challenges and implications of Sudan's case against the UAE at the ICJ, focusing on allegations of the UAE's support for the RSF and the ensuing genocidal acts against the Masalit people.
headings: Prospect of ICJ Masalit Genocide Case
Quazi Omar Foysal
March 17, 2025
Sudan's Legal Action Against the UAE

Sudan has initiated proceedings against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), alleging that the UAE is violating obligations under the Genocide Convention by supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) accused of committing genocidal acts against the Masalit group in Darfur.
Historical Context and Previous Accusations

The allegations are not new; Sudan has previously accused the UAE of supporting the RSF in statements at the United Nations General Assembly and the UN Security Council. The United States has also accused the RSF of committing genocide and imposed sanctions on UAE-based companies linked to the RSF and its leader, Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo.
Legal Challenges and Jurisdictional Issues

The case presents several legal challenges, including questions about the ICJ's jurisdiction based on Article IX of the Genocide Convention, the UAE's reservations to this article, and the attribution of responsibility for the alleged genocidal acts.
Potential Outcomes and International Implications

The outcome of this case could have significant implications for international law, particularly concerning state responsibility for complicity in genocide and the enforcement of the Genocide Convention.

34.title: Sudan files case against UAE at top UN court over 'complicity in genocide'
34.description: Sudan has initiated legal proceedings against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the UAE of violating the Genocide Convention by supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), implicated in atrocities against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
34.keywords: Sudan, UAE, ICJ, Genocide Convention, Rapid Support Forces, RSF, Masalit, West Darfur, international law
34.author: The Business Standard
34.og_title: Sudan files case against UAE at top UN court over 'complicity in genocide'
34.og_description: Sudan has filed a case at the International Court of Justice accusing the UAE of breaching the Genocide Convention by supporting the RSF, implicated in genocidal acts against the Masalit people.
headings: Sudan files case against UAE at top UN court over 'complicity in genocide'
The Business Standard
March 6, 2025
Sudan has initiated legal proceedings against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the UAE of violating its obligations under the Genocide Convention.

The case centers on allegations that the UAE provided financial and military support to the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a paramilitary group implicated in atrocities against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
The Sudanese government asserts that this support amounts to complicity in acts of genocide, murder, rape, and other human rights violations committed by the RSF.
The UAE has dismissed the allegations as baseless and stated its intention to seek immediate dismissal of the case.

The conflict between the Sudanese Armed Forces and the RSF, which began in April 2023, has resulted in significant loss of life and displacement, with the Masalit community in West Darfur particularly affected.
The ICJ's rulings are legally binding, but the judicial process can be protracted, with final decisions potentially taking years.

35.title: Sudan vs UAE at the ICJ: Why Darfur genocide claims are in focus
35.description: An analysis of Sudan's legal case against the United Arab Emirates at the International Court of Justice, alleging the UAE's complicity in genocide due to its support for the Rapid Support Forces implicated in atrocities against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
35.keywords: Sudan, UAE, ICJ, Genocide Convention, Rapid Support Forces, RSF, Masalit, West Darfur, international law
35.author: Matthew Hoare
35.og_title: Sudan vs UAE at the ICJ: Why Darfur genocide claims are in focus
35.og_description: An exploration of the legal implications and challenges of Sudan's case against the UAE at the ICJ, focusing on allegations of the UAE's support for the RSF and the resulting genocidal acts against the Masalit people.
headings: Sudan vs UAE at the ICJ: Why Darfur genocide claims are in focus
Matthew Hoare
March 8, 2025

Sudan has filed a case against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the Gulf state of complicity in genocide due to its alleged backing of the rebel Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia.
In its application, Sudan has accused the UAE of being 'complicit in the genocide' allegedly carried out by the RSF against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
It alleges that Abu Dhabi has provided 'extensive financial, political and military support' to the rebel group as it wages war against the country's armed forces.

The militia has been accused of perpetrating several massacres against the Masalit in West Darfur since the country's civil war broke out in April 2023. According to a UN report, between 10,000 and 15,000 people were killed in a single city during 2023.
The governor of West Darfur, Khamis Abakar, described the killings as a genocide shortly before he was killed by the RSF in 2023.
Sudan wants the 15 judges on the panel to approve provisional measures ordering the UAE to prevent acts of genocide being perpetrated in Darfur.
The ICJ is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations and settles legal disputes between states. Its rulings are binding, but the court has no means to enforce them.
Sudan's application is likely to face significant hurdles before it is accepted by the court.
The UAE has made a reservation to Article IX of the Genocide Convention, which grants the ICJ jurisdiction over disputes between contracting parties.
This means that the court may not have jurisdiction to hear the case unless the UAE consents to it.
Even if the court finds that it has jurisdiction, Sudan will need to provide evidence that the UAE was complicit in the alleged genocide.

Complicity in genocide requires a high threshold of proof, and Sudan will need to demonstrate that the UAE had knowledge of the RSF's intent to commit genocide and provided support that had a substantial effect on the commission of the crime.
The case highlights the challenges of holding states accountable for their alleged involvement in atrocities committed by non-state actors in foreign conflicts.

36.title: Sudan files case against UAE at ICJ for 'complicity in genocide'
36.description: Sudan has filed a case at the International Court of Justice accusing the United Arab Emirates of complicity in genocide due to its alleged support for the Rapid Support Forces implicated in atrocities against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
36.keywords: Sudan, UAE, ICJ, Genocide Convention, Rapid Support Forces, RSF, Masalit, West Darfur, international law
36.author: The New Arab Staff & Agencies
36.og_title: Sudan files case against UAE at ICJ for 'complicity in genocide'
36.og_description: Sudan has filed a case at the International Court of Justice accusing the UAE of complicity in genocide due to its alleged support for the RSF implicated in atrocities against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
headings: Sudan files case against UAE at ICJ for 'complicity in genocide'
The New Arab Staff & Agencies
March 6, 2025

Sudan has filed a case against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the Gulf state of complicity in genocide over its alleged support for Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF).

Khartoum contends the UAE is 'complicit in the genocide on the Masalit [community in Sudan] through its direction of and provision of extensive financial, political, and military support for the rebel RSF militia,' the ICJ said in a statement.
The UAE, which has repeatedly denied supporting the RSF, dismissed the case as a 'publicity stunt' and said it would try to have it thrown out.

The case 'is nothing more than a cynical publicity stunt aimed at diverting attention,' a UAE official said in a statement, adding: 'The UAE will seek the immediate dismissal of this baseless application.'

For nearly two years, the RSF and the regular army in Sudan have fought a war that has killed tens of thousands of people and uprooted more than 12 million. Famine has been declared in parts of the country.

37.title: Sudan sues UAE for complicity in Darfur genocide
37.description: Sudan has initiated legal proceedings against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), accusing the UAE of violating the Genocide Convention by supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) implicated in genocidal acts against the Masalit people in West Darfur.
37.keywords: Sudan, UAE, ICJ, Genocide Convention, Rapid Support Forces, RSF, Masalit, West Darfur, international law
37.author: Jurist
37.og_title: Sudan sues UAE for complicity in Darfur genocide
37.og_description: An analysis of Sudan's legal action against the UAE at the ICJ, focusing on allegations of the UAE's support for the RSF and the implications for international justice.
headings: Sudan sues UAE for complicity in Darfur genocide
Jurist
March 15, 2025

Sudan has instituted proceedings against the United Arab Emirates (UAE) before the International Court of Justice (ICJ), alleging that the UAE has directly supported the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and its associated militias in West Darfur state, thereby violating the Genocide Convention.

The claim is based on weapons seized by the Sudanese Armed Forces in active war zones, including armored personnel carriers and 4×4 combat vehicles originating from the UAE. Sudan asserts that these supplies have enabled the RSF to commit genocidal acts in West Darfur, such as killings of civilians and deprivation of access to medical care and basic necessities.

Additionally, Sudan accuses the UAE of providing travel assistance to the RSF's commander-in-chief and hosting RSF business activities, actions that allegedly violate U.S. sanctions. In January 2025, the U.S. imposed sanctions on RSF leader Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo and seven RSF-linked companies based in the UAE for committing genocide.

The dispute pertains to the fulfillment of the Genocide Convention's Article III prohibition on 'complicity with genocide.' Although the UAE acceded to the convention, its express reservation to the dispute resolution clause under Article IX may present a hurdle for the ICJ to assume jurisdiction.
Pending final judgment, Sudan has requested provisional measures, including requiring the UAE to 'take all measures within its power' to prevent genocidal acts against Darfur's Masalit ethnic group.
In response, UAE Foreign Minister Anwar Gargash stated on social media that Sudan should prioritize a ceasefire over a 'publicity tactic' to justify its rejection of peace.

38.title: Sudan’s war: What’s driving UAE and Saudi Arabia interests?
38.description: An analysis of the roles and motivations of the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia in the Sudanese civil war, focusing on their historical ties, economic interests, and geopolitical strategies in the region.
38.keywords: Sudan, UAE, Saudi Arabia, civil war, Rapid Support Forces, economic interests, geopolitical strategy
38.author: Federico Donelli
38.og_title: Sudan’s war: What’s driving UAE and Saudi Arabia interests?
38.og_description: An exploration of the involvement of the UAE and Saudi Arabia in Sudan's civil war, examining their economic and geopolitical interests, including historical ties, investments in agriculture and gold, and strategic positioning in the Red Sea region.
headings: Sudan’s war: What’s driving UAE and Saudi Arabia interests?
Federico Donelli
March 16, 2025

The civil war in Sudan that began in April 2023 involves several external actors. The conflict pits the Sudanese Armed Forces against the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces in a quest for political and economic power. The situation has created one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises. Various foreign states have picked a side to support. They include Chad, Egypt, Iran, Libya, Qatar, Russia, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates (UAE).

In particular, Saudi Arabia and the UAE are providing financial and military support to the warring parties, although they have denied it. Political scientist Federico Donelli, who has studied the influence of these Gulf monarchies in Sudan, unpacks the implications of their intervention.
How did the UAE and Saudi Arabia get involved in Sudan?
Domestic factors within Sudan were the primary triggers for the outbreak of the civil war. Framing the Sudanese conflict as a proxy war may underestimate or overlook important internal variables.

But it’s also important to highlight the indirect involvement of other states. In the Horn of Africa region, Sudan has interacted the most with Middle Eastern states over the past two decades. Among these states, two Gulf monarchies – Saudi Arabia and the UAE – stand out.

Political relations between Saudi Arabia and Sudan date back to the independence of the Sudanese state in 1956. And people-to-people links have flourished over centuries. This is largely because Sudan is geographically close to Saudi and the two Muslim holy cities of Mecca (Makkah) and Medina.

The case of the UAE is different. Since the beginning of the new millennium, the Emirates have expanded their economic and financial influence in Africa, investing in niche sectors such as port logistics. Sudan in particular came to the fore for the Emirates after the secession of South Sudan in 2011. The UAE invested in the agricultural sector, acquiring large tracts of land to ensure food security.

The UAE also invested in the gold sector. Gold has been one of the main drivers of the Sudan conflict. It allows both parties to fuel their war machines. The UAE is the main beneficiary of this trade. It receives nearly all the gold smuggled from Sudan and has become a hub for laundering trafficked gold into the global market. The latest available statistics show that, officially, the UAE imported precious metals from Sudan valued at about US$2.3 billion in 2022.
What are the interests of the two Gulf monarchies in Sudan?
The UAE and Saudi Arabia have multiple interests in Sudan. These include:
Economic interests: Both countries have invested heavily in Sudan’s agriculture and mining sectors. They see Sudan as a source of food security and a supplier of precious metals.

Geopolitical interests: Sudan’s strategic location along the Red Sea makes it a key player in regional politics. The UAE and Saudi Arabia aim to counter the influence of rivals like Iran and Turkey in the region.
Security interests: Both Gulf monarchies seek to ensure that Sudan does not become a haven for extremist groups that could threaten their own security.
How have the UAE and Saudi Arabia influenced the Sudanese conflict?

The involvement of the UAE and Saudi Arabia has had a significant impact on the dynamics of the Sudanese conflict. Their financial and military support has emboldened the warring parties, making them less willing to negotiate and prolonging the conflict.

Moreover, their competition for influence in Sudan has further complicated the situation. While both countries support the Sudanese Armed Forces, they have also cultivated relationships with different factions within the military and political spheres, leading to a fragmented and unstable environment.
What are the implications of their involvement for the future of Sudan?
The involvement of the UAE and Saudi Arabia in Sudan’s conflict poses several challenges for the country’s future:
Prolonged conflict: Their support for the warring parties may lead to a protracted conflict, resulting in more casualties and displacement.
Undermined sovereignty: The heavy influence of foreign powers undermines Sudan’s sovereignty and hampers its ability to make independent decisions.
Obstructed peace efforts: The competing interests of the UAE and Saudi Arabia may hinder coordinated international efforts to broker peace in Sudan.

In conclusion, while domestic factors are the primary drivers of the Sudanese conflict, the involvement of external actors like the UAE and Saudi Arabia has exacerbated the situation. Their economic, geopolitical, and security interests have led them to support different factions, prolonging the conflict and complicating efforts to achieve peace.

39.title: UAE-Backed RSF Militia's Genocide Against the Masalit Tribe in Darfur
39.description: An in-depth report on the alleged genocide committed by the UAE-supported Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia against the Masalit ethnic group in Darfur, Sudan, including details of atrocities and the ensuing legal actions.
39.keywords: Sudan, UAE, RSF, Masalit, Darfur, genocide, International Court of Justice, human rights violations
39.author: Al-Estiklal Newspaper
39.og_title: UAE-Backed RSF Militia's Genocide Against the Masalit Tribe in Darfur
39.og_description: An investigation into the alleged genocide perpetrated by the UAE-backed RSF militia against the Masalit tribe in Darfur, highlighting the atrocities committed and Sudan's legal response.
headings: UAE-Backed RSF Militia's Genocide Against the Masalit Tribe in Darfur
Al-Estiklal Newspaper
March 16, 2025
Massacres are not new in Sudan, where the ongoing civil war between the military and the Emirati-backed RSF militia has claimed the lives of thousands of civilians.
However, a particularly tragic chapter is unfolding in Darfur, where the Masalit tribe faced a genocide in 2023.
Harrowing testimonies and reports have emerged, accusing the RSF militia, with alleged Emirati backing, of killing, burning, and raping members of the tribe.
This has led Sudan to file a request on March 6, 2025, to pursue legal action against the UAE at the International Court of Justice.
Sudanese authorities accuse the UAE of fueling the war in their country by backing the RSF militia.

Since April 2023, the Sudanese military and the RSF militia have been locked in a brutal conflict, leaving over 20,000 dead and nearly 15 million displaced, according to the United Nations and local authorities. However, a study by American universities estimates the death toll to be around 130,000.
Genocide Allegations

On March 6, the International Court of Justice announced that Sudan had filed a request to bring a case against the UAE regarding allegations of violations under the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. The case specifically pertains to the mistreatment of the Masalit people in Sudan, particularly in the western region of Darfur.

In its statement, the court added that Sudan's request concerns 'acts committed by' the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and allied militias, including 'but not limited to, genocide, murder, theft of property, rape, forcible displacement, damage to property, and human rights violations.'
According to the statement, 'all these acts were committed and facilitated through the direct support provided to the RSF militia and related militia groups by the United Arab Emirates.'

Sudan’s request also pertains to 'actions adopted, approved, and carried out by the Government of the United Arab Emirates concerning the genocide against the Masalit group in the Republic of Sudan since at least 2023.'

According to the statement, Sudan claims that the UAE is 'complicit in the genocide against the Masalit by directing and providing extensive financial, political, and military support to the Rapid Support Forces militia.'

It also noted that the plaintiff (Sudan) seeks to establish the court’s jurisdiction under Article 36, paragraph 1, of the Court’s Statute and Article 9 of the Genocide Convention, to which both Sudan and the UAE are parties.
Provisional Measures
According to the statement, Sudan requests the court to consider the following interim measures pending a final judgment in the case:

Firstly, 'In accordance with its obligations under the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, with respect to the Masalit in the Republic of Sudan, the United Arab Emirates is required to take all measures within its power to prevent the commission of any acts falling under Article II of this Convention, specifically:
(a) Killing members of the group.
(b) Causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group.
(c) Imposing living conditions intended to bring about its total or partial destruction.
(d) Enforcing measures aimed at preventing reproduction within the group.'

Secondly, 'The United Arab Emirates, with respect to members of the Masalit group, must ensure that no irregular armed units under its direction or support, nor any organizations or individuals subject to its control, direction, or influence, commit any acts described in point (1) above, or conspire to commit genocide, or directly and publicly incite genocide, or attempt to commit genocide.'

40.title: UAE's Secret Washington Talks: Tahnoun bin Zayed Negotiates High-Stakes Deals on Sudan, Syria, and Gaza
40.description: In covert meetings with U.S. officials, UAE National Security Advisor Tahnoun bin Zayed discusses strategic deals concerning Sudan, Syria, and Gaza, aiming to influence U.S. policy and expand UAE's regional influence.
40.keywords: UAE, Tahnoun bin Zayed, Washington talks, Sudan, Syria, Gaza, U.S. foreign policy, Middle East diplomacy
40.author: Basil Al Sayed
40.og_title: UAE's Secret Washington Talks: Tahnoun bin Zayed Negotiates High-Stakes Deals on Sudan, Syria, and Gaza
40.og_description: UAE National Security Advisor Tahnoun bin Zayed holds closed-door meetings with U.S. officials, discussing strategic deals that could shift power dynamics in the Middle East, focusing on Sudan, Syria, and Gaza.
headings: UAE's Secret Washington Talks: Tahnoun bin Zayed Negotiates High-Stakes Deals on Sudan, Syria, and Gaza
Basil Al Sayed
March 17, 2025

In a covert intelligence move, UAE National Security Advisor Tahnoun bin Zayed traveled to Washington for closed-door meetings with the administration of U.S. President Donald Trump, according to leaks from Abu Dhabi.
Speculation is growing over potential strategic deals involving Sudan, Syria, and Gaza, which could reshape the balance of power in the Middle East.
Leaks from UAE decision-making circles suggest that Tahnoun aims to convince the Trump administration to:
Shield Abu Dhabi from international sanctions or diplomatic pressure over its support for the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia.
Influence the International Court of Justice (ICJ) to block investigations into war crimes committed by RSF.
Ensure that the U.S. does not impose sanctions on the UAE for its involvement in Sudan.
The Proposed Deal:
Securing major military and security deals between the UAE and U.S. defense companies.
Enhancing intelligence coordination between Abu Dhabi and Washington to whitewash the UAE’s role in Sudan.
The Secret Mission:
Concealing any evidence of the UAE arming RSF.
Mobilizing American lobbying groups to freeze any legal action against the UAE.
Syria: UAE Seeks to Replace Iranian Influence
Tahnoun brings to Washington a strategic plan to reshape Syria by:
Supporting UAE-backed factions to counter Iranian influence.
Undermining the recent SDF-Damascus agreement to prevent stability that could benefit Iran.
Coordinating covert operations inside Syria with Israel and Washington.
The Proposed Deal:
Securing U.S. support for UAE influence in Syria as an alternative to Iran.
Ensuring continued Israeli airstrikes on Syria under diplomatic cover from Abu Dhabi.
The Secret Mission:
Funding sabotage operations inside Syria using mercenaries and operatives.
Promoting separatism among minority groups with Israeli-backed guarantees.
Providing diplomatic backing to Israel for ongoing airstrikes on Syrian territory.

41.title: Lawmakers Move to Block Arms Sales to UAE Over Sudan Conflict
41.description: U.S. lawmakers are pushing to halt arms transfers to the United Arab Emirates following reports it has armed Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a militia accused of war crimes. Proposed legislation seeks to tighten export controls and sanction states fueling the conflict.
41.keywords: UAE, Sudan, RSF, arms sales, Gregory Meeks, U.S. Congress, sanctions, war crimes, Middle East, foreign policy
41.author: Nahal Toosi
41.og_title: Lawmakers Move to Block Arms Sales to UAE Over Sudan Conflict
41.og_description: In response to UAE support for Sudan’s RSF militia, U.S. lawmakers propose halting arms sales and increasing sanctions to deter further destabilisation.
headings: Lawmakers Move to Block Arms Sales to UAE Over Sudan Conflict
Nahal Toosi
March 7, 2025
U.S. lawmakers are growing increasingly concerned over reports that the UAE has supplied weapons and funding to the RSF militia in Sudan, a group accused of committing atrocities.
Representative Gregory Meeks has held up arms sales to the UAE since late 2024 and plans to introduce new legislation titled the U.S. Engagement in Sudanese Peace Act.
Proposed measures would include:
Barring U.S. arms transfers to any country supporting combatants in Sudan.
Expanding sanctions against armed groups and their supporters.
Funding a special U.S. envoy to help broker peace in Sudan.
Additional legislation is being drafted by Senator Chris Van Hollen and Representative Sara Jacobs, focusing specifically on the UAE’s role.
The Sudan conflict has killed around 150,000 people and displaced millions, with the RSF accused of war crimes and genocide.
Sudan submitted a formal complaint to the UN Security Council in late 2024, accusing the UAE of supplying arms and transporting RSF fighters for medical care in Abu Dhabi.
Evidence included images of UAE-marked ammunition boxes and vehicles linked to RSF operations.
The UAE denies wrongdoing, but U.S. lawmakers say further scrutiny is essential to uphold international law.
